Automated Machine Learning with H2O (II)

Author

Gani Cem Türemen

1 Challenge Summary

For the challenge, we shall be working with a Product Backorders dataset. The goal here is to predict whether or not a product will be put on backorder status, given a number of product metrics such as current inventory, transit time, demand forecasts and prior sales. It’s a classic Binary Classification problem.

2 Objectives

We will apply our learning of H2O Automated Machine Learning to predict backorder status.

3 Solution

3.1 Import Libraries

library(tidyverse)
library(recipes)
library(rsample)
library(readxl)
library(h2o)

3.2 Load the training & test dataset

product_backorders_tbl <- read_csv("data/product_backorders.csv")

product_backorders_tbl %>% glimpse()

#> $ rev_stop          <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
#> $ went_on_backorder <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Ye…

Split the data into training and test sets:

set.seed(seed = 777)
split_obj <- initial_split(product_backorders_tbl, prop = 0.80)

train_set_tbl <- training(split_obj)
test_set_tbl  <- testing(split_obj)

Since some columns such as deck_risk are not numeric, they have to be converted into factor. The recipe below will take care of that:

recipe_obj <- recipe(went_on_backorder ~., data = train_set_tbl) %>% 
  step_zv(all_predictors()) %>% 
  step_mutate_at(potential_issue,
                 deck_risk,
                 oe_constraint,
                 ppap_risk,
                 stop_auto_buy,
                 rev_stop,
                 went_on_backorder,
                 fn = as.factor) %>% 
  prep()

train_tbl <- bake(recipe_obj, new_data = train_set_tbl)
test_tbl  <- bake(recipe_obj, new_data = test_set_tbl)

train_tbl %>% glimpse()
#> Rows: 15,242
#> Columns: 23
#> $ sku               <dbl> 1370478, 1423347, 1704266, 2258894, 3000725, 2888766…
#> $ national_inv      <dbl> 4, 59, 1, 9, 151, 6, 195, 66, 52, 0, 25, 1, 4, 2, 10…
#> $ lead_time         <dbl> 12, NA, 8, 2, 8, 2, 8, 8, 14, 2, 4, 4, 8, 8, 2, 8, 5…

#> $ rev_stop          <fct> No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, …
#> $ went_on_backorder <fct> No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No…

3.3 Specify the response and predictor variables

To determine the backorder status went_on_backorder, all the other columns will be used as predictors:

h2o.init()

split_h2o <- h2o.splitFrame(as.h2o(train_tbl), ratios = c(0.80), seed = 767)
train_h2o <- split_h2o[[1]]
valid_h2o <- split_h2o[[2]]
test_h2o  <- as.h2o(test_tbl)

y <- "went_on_backorder"
x <- setdiff(names(train_h2o), y)

3.4 Run AutoML specifying the stopping criterion

Set 30 seconds for max_runtime_secs and 5 for nfolds:

automl_models_h2o <- h2o.automl(
  x = x,
  y = y,
  training_frame    = train_h2o,
  validation_frame  = valid_h2o,
  leaderboard_frame = test_h2o,
  max_runtime_secs  = 30,
  nfolds            = 5 
)

3.5 View the leaderboard

automl_models_h2o@leaderboard
#>                                                  model_id       auc   logloss
#> 1                          GBM_1_AutoML_1_20230606_235930 0.9217779 0.2278932
#> 2 StackedEnsemble_BestOfFamily_1_AutoML_1_20230606_235930 0.9216773 0.2214933
#> 3                          DRF_1_AutoML_1_20230606_235930 0.7456369 2.7271022
#> 4                          GLM_1_AutoML_1_20230606_235930 0.7403997 0.3303213
#>       aucpr mean_per_class_error      rmse        mse
#> 1 0.6257940            0.1667248 0.2612527 0.06825299
#> 2 0.6303983            0.1693529 0.2611982 0.06822452
#> 3 0.3779712            0.2808203 0.3280305 0.10760404
#> 4 0.2842939            0.3237555 0.3133306 0.09817608
#> 
#> [4 rows x 7 columns]

3.6 Predicting using Leader Model

Extract the first model of the leaderboard:

leader_model <- automl_models_h2o@leaderboard %>% 
  extract_h2o_model_name_by_position(1) %>% 
  h2o.getModel()
#> GBM_1_AutoML_1_20230606_235930

Use the extracted model to make predictions on the test set:

predictions <- h2o.predict(leader_model, newdata = as.h2o(test_tbl))

predictions_tbl <- predictions %>% as_tibble()

predictions_tbl %>% glimpse()
#> Rows: 3,811
#> Columns: 3
#> $ predict <fct> Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes…
#> $ No      <dbl> 0.7289282, 0.5590327, 0.5837228, 0.4468112, 0.8088230, 0.57161…
#> $ Yes     <dbl> 0.27107175, 0.44096726, 0.41627720, 0.55318882, 0.19117701, 0.…

3.7 Save the leader model

Save the extracted model in case it is needed later:

leader_model %>% h2o.saveModel(path = "h2o_models/")
